page.title: 15LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS (ii)
page.content: There are 3 granite crosses: at Week Down,nearby Short Cross,and Beetor Cross at Watching-place. Dates are uncertain, but they may have been carved by the earliest Christians 7th.-9th.C. Beetor Cross is reputed to be where the Celts awaited Saxon invasion, prior to a battle.It is also said food was put out here at the time of the Plague, and that a gibbet stood here. There is a bee-wall, possibly 18th.C at Beetor farm ,for holding skeps. A blowing house remains at Outer Down, two mould stones (for molten tin) being incorporated in the wall.There are several ash houses(e.g. Nattadon).Ash was removed to reduce risk of fires and for fertiliser. The "Druids well" beside the road at Middlecott is believed to be a butterwell, for cooling butter.
